text: Applications
ACE 3-1

Find each product.

a. 7 ∙ 2

b. -7 ∙ (-2)

c. 7 ∙ (-2)

d. -7 ∙ 2

e. 8 ∙ 2.5

f. -9 ∙ (-4)

g. 12 ∙ (-3)

h. -1.5 ∙ 4

i. 3.5 ∙ 7

j. -8.1 ∙ (-1)

k. 1 ∙ (-6)

l. -2½ ∙ 1

a. 7 ∙ 2 = 14

b. -7 ∙ (-2) = 14

c. 7 ∙ (-2) = -14

d. -7 ∙ 2 = -14

e. 8 ∙ 2.5 = 20

f. -9 ∙ (-4) = 36

g. 12 ∙ (-3) = -36

h. -1.5 ∙ 4 = -6

i. 3.5 ∙ 7 = 24.5

j. -8.1 ∙ (-1) = 8.1

k. 1 ∙ (-6) = -6

l. -2 ½ ∙ 1 = -2 ½

ACE 3-3

Julia thinks a bit more about how to use chips to model operations with integers. She draws the following chip board. She decides it represents 8・(-5) = -40 and -40 ÷ 8 = -5. Explain why Julia’s reasoning makes sense.
There are 8 red chips, each with a value of -5. Thus, the total value of the board, by adding, is -40. This means 8 × (-5) = -40 or -40 ÷ 8 = -5

• 10 x (-5) = -50 (add 10 terms, each of which is -5).
  • 4 x (-15) = -60 = (-15) + (-15) + (-15) + (-15)
  • 3 x (-5) = -15 = -5 + (-5) + (-5)
  • -14 ÷ 2 = 7 since 2 × (-7) = -14 = -7 + (-7)
  • -14 ÷ 7 = -2 since (-2) × 7 = -14
  • -35 ÷ 7 = -5 since (-5) × 7 = -35

ACE 3-5

Determine whether the product of or quotient of each expression is greater than, less than, or equal to 0 without doing any calculations. Explain your reasoning.

a. –1,105.62 ÷ 24.3 =

b. 0 ∙ (–67) =

c. –27.5 ∙ (–63) =

d. 0 ÷ 89 =

e. –54.9 ÷ (–3) =

f. –2,943 ∙ 1.06 =

a. < 0 (A negative number divided by a positive number will always be a negative number.)

b. = 0 (Any number multiplied by 0 is 0.)

c. > 0 (A negative multiplied by a negative results in a positive.)

d. = 0 (0 divided by any nonzero number, regardless of sign, is 0.)

e. > 0 (A negative divided by a negative results in a positive.)

f. < 0 (The product of a negative and a positive is a negative.)
ACE 3-6

You have located fractions such as -(5/7) on a number line. You have also used fractions to show division: (-5)/7 = -5 ÷ 7 and 5/(-7) = 5 ÷ (-7). Tell whether each statement is true or false. Explain.
a. True. You can either distribute the negative sign (that is out front) to the numerator or the denominator. In either of the forms, it will still be a negative answer. (-1)/2 = 1/(-2)
b. False. -(1/2) = -0.5, but (-1)/(-2) = 0.5. In (-1)/(-2), both numbers are negative, and a negative divided by a negative equals a positive. -1 ÷ (-2) = 0.5.

ACE 3-10

What six factors do they need for their game? Explain your reasoning.
ACE 3-11

Find integers to make each sentence true.

a. ___ x ___ = 30

b. ___ x ___ = -30

c. -24 ÷ ___ = ___

a. Answers will vary. Possible answer: -6 * -5 or -10 * -3

b. Answers will vary. Possible answers: 6 * -5 or -5 * 6 or -10 * 3

c. Answers will vary. Possible answers: 8 and -3 or -6 and 4
Connections
ACE 3-12

The temperature changed -2℉ per hour from noon on Tuesday until 10:00 A.M. the next morning. The temperature at noon on Tuesday is shown.

a. What was the temperature at 4:00 P.M. on Tuesday?

b. What was the temperature at 9:00 A.M. on Wednesday?

a. Answers will vary based on students’ estimates of the thermometer reading. Sample: There are 4 h between noon and 4:00 P.M. In 4 h, the temperature changes 4 ∙ (-2) = -8℉, so the temperature at 4:00 P.M. was 69 + (-8) = 61℉.

b. Answers will vary based on students’ estimates of the thermometer reading. Sample: There are 21 h between noon and 9:00 A.M. In 21 h, the temperature changes 21 ∙ (-2) = -42℉, so the temperature at 9:00 A.M. was 69 + (-42) = 27℉.

Write equivalent expressions to show two different ways to find the area of each rectangle. Use the ideas of the Distributive Property.
ACE 3-15

The list below gives average temperatures (in ℃) for a city for each month of the year, from January through December.

-25, -20, -13, -2, 9, 15, 17, 14, 7, -4, -16, -23

a. What is the median?

b. What is the range?

c. What is the mean?

d. Number the months from 1 (for January) through 12 (for December). Plot a graph of the month, temperature) data.

a. The temperatures measured in ℃ from the lowest to highest are: -25, -23, -20, -16, -13, -4, -2, 7, 9, 14, 15, 17. The median falls between the sixth and seventh temperatures, or between -2 and -4, which is a median of -3℃.

b. The temperature goes from -25℃ to 17℃, giving a range of 42℃.

c. The sum of all the temperatures is -41℃, giving a mean temperature of -41℃ ÷ 12 ≈ -3.4℃.

d. See below
ACE 3-16

Complete each pair of calculations.

a. 12 ÷ (-8 + 4) = ? and [12 ÷ (-8)] + (12 ÷ 4) = ?

b. -12 ÷ [-5 - (-3)] = ? and [-12 ÷ (-5)] - [-12 ÷ (-3)] = ?

c. (-2 - 6) ÷ 4 = ? and (-2 ÷ 4) - (6 ÷ 4) = ?

d. (5 + 6) ÷ 3 = ? and (5 ÷ 3) + (6 ÷ 3) = ?

e. What can you conclude from parts (a)-(d) about the Distributive Property?

a. 12 ÷ (-8 + 4) = -3; [12 ÷ (-8)] + (12 ÷ 4) = 1.5

b. -12 ÷ [-5 - (-3)] = 6; [-12 ÷ (-15)] - [-12 ÷ (-3)] = -1.6

c. -2

d. 11/3

e. Division does not distribute over addition or subtraction. When the dividend is a sum or difference of two numbers and the divisor is a rational number, the Distributive Property works. However, when the dividend is a rational number and the divisor is a sum or difference of two numbers, then the Distributive Property does not work.

ACE 3-21
Write a related equation. Use it to find the value of n that makes the sentence true.

a. n - (-5) = 35; n = 35 + (-5); 5 = 35 - n; answers will vary for the related fact. n=30. Some students find the “missing addend” problem to be easier to reason, but other students may find one of the other forms easier, such as n = 35 + (-5).

b. 4 + n = -43; n = -43 - 4; 4 = -43 - n; n = -47

c. -2n = -16; n = -16 ∙ (-½ ); n = 8

d. n/4 = -32; n = -32 ∙ 4; n = -128
Extensions
ACE 3-22

Determine whether each statement is always, sometimes or never true. Explain your reasoning.

a. If m and n are positive rational numbers, then m + n is positive.

b. If m and n are negative rational numbers, then m + n is negative.

c. If m is a positive rational number and n is a negative rational number, then m + n is negative.

d. If m and n are positive rational numbers, then m × n is positive.

e. If m and n are negative rational numbers, then m × n is negative.

a. Always; The sum of two positive rational numbers is positive.

b. Always; The sum of two negative rational numbers is negative.

c. Sometimes; The sign of the sum of a positive and negative rational number is the same as the sign of the number with the greatest absolute value.

d. Always; The product of two positive rational numbers is positive.

e. Never; The product of two negative rational numbers is positive.
ACE 3-23

To add 5 + 3 + 2, you might think that it is easier to add the 3 + 2 and then add the answer to the 5. The mathematical property that allows you to change the grouping of addends (or factors) is called the Associative Property.

Test the Associative Property for addition and multiplication of integers by simplifying the expressions below. Find the values within the parentheses first. When you need a grouping symbol like parentheses inside another set of parentheses, you can use brackets to make it easier to read. For example, (4 – ( -6)) can be written as [4 – (-6)].

a. [3 ∙ (-3)] ∙ 4 and 3 ∙ (-3 ∙ 4)

b. (-5 ∙ 4) ∙ (-3) and -5 ∙ [4 ∙ (-3)]

c. [-2 ∙ (-3)] ∙ (-5) and -2 ∙ [-3 ∙ (-5)]

d. (3 ∙ 4) ∙ (-5) and 3 ∙ [4 ∙ (-5)]

e. [3 + (-3)] + 4 and 3 + (-3 + 4)

f. (-5 + 4) + (-3) and -5 + [4 + (-3)]

g. [-2 + (-3)] + (-5) and -2 + [-3 + (-5)]

h. (3 + 4) + (-5) and 3 + [4 + (-5)]

i. Does the Associative Property work for addition and multiplication of integers?

a. -9 ∙ 4 = -36 and 3 ∙ (-12) = -36

b. -20 ∙ (-3) = 60 and -5 ∙ (-12) = 60

c. 6 ∙ (-5) = -30 and -2 ∙ 15 = -30

d. 12 ∙ (-5) = -60 and 3 ∙ (-20) = -60

e. 0 + 4 = 4 and 3 + 1 = 4

f. -1 + (-3) = -4 and -5 + 1 = -4

g. -5 + (-5) = -10 and -2 + (-8) = -10

h. 7 + (-5) = 2 and 3 + (-1) = 2

i. The Associative Property does work for addition and multiplication of integers.
ACE 3-24
Tell whether each statement is true or false. Explain your reasoning.

a. True. Zero added to any number, positive or negative, will not change the value of the number. This is the Additive Identity.

b. False. -3 ⅜ = -27/8

c. True. -3/4 is equivalent to -0.75. Adding -6 and -0.75 gives -6.75.
ACE 3-25

Find a set of addends to make a Sum Game. Each sum on the board below should be the sum of two numbers (possibly a single number added to itself). Each pair of numbers should add to a sum on the board.

Hint: You need 11 numbers, all with different absolute values.
